Chapter 5: Practice of Peace and Bliss (5) Chapter 5: Practice of Peace and Bliss
At that time, the World-Honored One again told the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Who Subdues All Obstacles:
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who practice ten dharmas are always peaceful and happily dwell wherever they are.
What are the ten?

Namely, well cultivating mindfulness and observing the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas, well cultivating mindfulness and observing the realm, the araá¹‡ya, the villages, cities, and towns, the offerings and respect received, the precepts established by the TathÄgatas, the upper, middle, and lower levels of afflictions in the skin, flesh, and heart, and well cultivating mindfulness to observe them.
Good man!
How do bodhisattvas observe the body and peacefully dwell?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe this body with wisdom, from the feet to the top of the head, only seeing this body composed of thirty-six substances provisionally combined into a person, moment by moment arising and ceasing, impermanent and decaying, held together by sinews and veins, filled with impurities, with nothing enjoyable. Observing in this way, they give rise to revulsion.
Because of revulsion, defilements of the body, greed for the body, views of the body, and attachments to the body all no longer arise.
For these causes and conditions, all that is unwholesome and associated with the body is completely abandoned, and all wholesome dharmas associated with the body are fully increased.
How does observing feelings and skillfully cultivating mindfulness lead to abiding in bliss?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate like this:
'All feelings are suffering.
Why is this?
Because infants and ordinary beings are foolish and ignorant, due to their delusions, they give rise to the notion of pleasure within painful feelings;
All sages only see this suffering, and are able to establish all sentient beings in this Dharma, enabling them to attain accord with it.
' Studying in this way, they have already attained the contemplation of feelings and well abide in the foundations of mindfulness, not being angry or greedy towards pleasant or painful feelings.
In order to extinguish feelings, they diligently cultivate mindfulness, and in this Dharma they exhort and transform others, enabling them to practice in this way.
How does one observe the foundation of mindfulness of the mind and abide in comfort?
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva thinks like this:

'This mind is inverted, with the thought of permanence in impermanence, the thought of pleasure in the arising of suffering, the thought of self in selfless dharmas, and the thought of purity in impurity. It is restless and changeable, not abiding for a moment. It serves as the root of all afflictions, long opening the gates to the three evil paths for sentient beings, serving as the causes and conditions for all suffering and distress, able to close the path of goodness, and able to give rise to greed, anger, and delusion, serving as the dominant condition for all dharmas.
All dharmas have the mind as their leader. If one knows the mind, then one can know all dharmas.

The mind is able to create all the various forms in the world. Only the mind sees the mind, and only the mind creates karma, whether good or bad. Only the mind transmigrates without temporary rest, like a fire wheel. Only the mind runs wild, like a bad horse. Only the mind is able to burn, like a forest fire. Only the mind nourishes life, like great water.
Contemplating in this way, abiding in the mindfulness of the mind, one is then able to not follow the mind, to be the master of the mind;
Because of being the master of the mind, one is then able to be the master of all dharmas.
If one is able to attain mastery over the mind, then one attains mastery over all dharmas.
How do bodhisattvas contemplate the mindfulness of dharmas and abide in bliss?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas truly understand that such unwholesome dharmas arise from the causes and conditions of greed, anger, and delusion, and from ignorance.

For this reason, they cultivate the methods of antidotes. If a greedy mind arises, they cultivate the contemplation of impurity. If an angry mind arises, they cultivate the contemplation of kindness and compassion. If a deluded mind arises, they cultivate the contemplation of the twelve links of dependent origination. They cultivate right effort to eliminate them.

Moreover, they observe all wholesome dharmas. Having seen wholesome dharmas, they concentrate their minds and abide in wholesome dharmas. They remember and observe, upholding these dharmas. Within these dharmas, they further encourage and transform others, causing sentient beings to abide within them.
How do bodhisattvas observe and contemplate the sense-spheres with concentrated mindfulness, abiding in bliss?
Bodhisattvas, regarding forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, whether good or bad, do not give rise to a mind of attachment, obstruction, greed, or anger.
They contemplate thus:
I should not give rise to such a mind. All dharmas are impermanent. How can I give rise to attachment?
If I am attached to these dharmas, I am foolish, ignorant, and deluded.
Why is it so?

As the Buddha said, because of longing and admiration one gives rise to defilement, because of defilement one grasps at objects, and because of delusion one is unable to understand good and bad dharmas. For this reason one will fall into evil destinies.
He further thinks like this:
'I should not give rise to such a mind, to be obstructed by impermanent dharmas.

If one gives rise to obstruction, one will be unable to endure it. Due to being unable to endure it, one will give rise to anger. Because of giving rise to anger, one will be scolded by the sages and reviled by all one's fellow students, and will not be praised.'
Having contemplated like this, one skillfully cultivates recollection towards hateful objects and abides in bliss.
How do bodhisattvas abide in bliss in a secluded place?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:
'A secluded place is the dwelling place of the samÄdhi of no dispute.
In this araá¹‡ya, there are many devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, etc., who have attained the knowledge of others' minds and can perceive my mind and mental factors.
Therefore, I should not give rise to any unwholesome thoughts in this forest.
If one can refrain from unwholesome thoughts towards all phenomena, one's practice will be accomplished and one will cultivate many wholesome dharmas.
How do bodhisattvas observe villages, towns, cities, and capitals and attain peaceful and blissful dwelling?
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter a village, if they see places where renunciant people are not suitable, they should avoid them from afar.
What are they?

Namely, places that sell alcohol, brothels, royal palaces, places for playing polo, etc., places where people gather to drink alcohol, and places where laypeople gather to perform music, sing, and dance.
They should completely avoid anything that is not suitable for renunciant life. This is the observation and peaceful abiding within.
How do bodhisattvas observe gains, respect, and fame in order to attain peaceful abiding?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, regarding all gains, benefactors, and meritorious deeds, should admonish and subdue their minds regarding these gains, not giving rise to attachment or fondness, and also not giving rise to a mind of self and possession. All the gains they obtain, they share equally with all suffering sentient beings, universally enjoying them together.
If due to these conditions they attain fame, regarding this fame they do not become arrogant, do not give rise to pride or self-indulgence, and think like this:
'The fame I have now obtained will soon disappear by itself. The one who attains fame and the fame obtained are all impermanent.
What wise person would become attached to these false, impermanent, fleeting, decaying, fragile, and unstable things, give rise to greed, or give rise to arrogance and contempt for others?
Contemplating in this way, one attains peaceful and joyful abiding.
How do bodhisattvas contemplate and observe the precepts established by the TathÄgatas, attaining peaceful and joyful abiding?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:

'All TathÄgatas of the past attained perfect enlightenment and parinirvÄá¹‡a by studying these precepts and Dharma-vinaya. All TathÄgatas of the future will attain perfect enlightenment and parinirvÄá¹‡a by studying these precepts and Dharma-vinaya. All TathÄgatas of the present are attaining perfect enlightenment and parinirvÄá¹‡a by studying these precepts and Dharma-vinaya.'

Having contemplated in this way, they wholeheartedly respect and revere the precepts and Dharma-vinaya, diligently seek this Dharma, practice wholesome dharmas, and attain peaceful and joyful abiding.
How do bodhisattvas observe and contemplate the three levels of afflictions - upper, middle, and lower - in the skin, flesh, and heart, and attain peaceful and joyful abiding?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe the afflictions in the skin and also observe the afflictions in the flesh and heart. By observing, they know the causes and conditions - from what causes and conditions do these afflictions arise, and on what do these causes and conditions depend to arise? They then know and see that the causes and conditions of afflictions are precisely ignorance.
The causes and conditions of ignorance are incorrect thoughts.
From what causes and conditions do incorrect thoughts arise?
It is from not listening to the true Dharma.
From what causes and conditions does not listening to the true Dharma arise?
It is from not associating with good friends.
Knowing this, one is able to completely avoid the causes and conditions of afflictions, the source of afflictions, and the objects of afflictions, and attain peaceful and joyful abiding.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who possess these ten qualities are always peaceful and joyful in their minds wherever they are.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities wear cast-off rags.
What are the ten?

Namely, upholding firmly, being humble and patient, having no weary mind, having no defiled mind, not seeing its faults, only seeing its merits, not being self-important, not despising others, being replete with pure precepts, and being worthy of the offerings, respect, and salutations of humans and gods.
How do bodhisattvas firmly uphold [the precepts]?
Good sons!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having accomplished the faculty of faith, harbor purity within, and in accordance with the precepts established by the TathÄgata, would rather lose their lives than deliberately violate them.
Having firmly upheld the precepts, they attain a humble mind;
because of the humble mind, arrogance does not arise;
because of the absence of arrogance, they pick up discarded, tattered, and worldly-rejected garments that are different from the robes worn by worldly people;

Having collected them, he washes, dyes, and sews them into robes, without giving rise to vexation or complaining of hardship, his mind free from fatigue and defilement, solely for the sake of accomplishing the merit of his practice.

In such rags, he does not see their faults, such as 'These rags are too big and torn,' 'They are too coarse and inferior,' 'They attract too many lice,' 'They are too tight on my body,' or 'They emit dirt and stains.'
For this reason, the bodhisattva observes the rags and sees only their merits - these rags are worn by all sages and saints, in accordance with non-desire and in accord with the holy lineage;
They are praised by all Buddhas, and he does not give rise to a sense of self-importance on this account, nor does he exalt himself or look down on others.
If one is free from arrogance, then one does not slight others;
Because one does not slight others, the precepts are complete;

Having perfected morality, they are worshipped, praised, and bowed to by all the Åšakras, Brahmas, and hosts of gods, are protected by all the Buddhas, are guarded by all the Bodhisattvas, are respected by humans and non-humans, are worshipped by kings, nobles, ministers, and the people, and are encouraged by all their fellow students.
Good man!
In this way, Bodhisattvas, possessing these ten qualities, wear cast-off rags.
The Bodhisattva Subduer of All Obstacles said:
World-Honored One!
Why do all Bodhisattvas delight in these inferior, coarse, and filthy cast-off rags, when the minds of all Bodhisattvas are vast?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

All Bodhisattvas wish to accomplish the power of vows in the entire world, but for those Bodhisattvas who have not yet accomplished the power of vows, in order to prevent afflictions from arising, they cultivate the Dharma gates of antidotes.
Good man!
What do you think?
Is the TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, of a magnanimous mind?ğŸ”½Or a mean and lowly mind?
Or a base and inferior mind?
He replied:
World-Honored One!
I do not have the eloquence to answer such words.
Why is it so?
World-Honored One!
The understanding and realization of the Buddhas, the TathÄgatas, is not within my realm.
Why is it so?

Only the World-Honored One has fully seen this Dharma, only the Sugata has fully seen this Dharma. There is not a single Dharma that the Buddhas, the TathÄgatas, do not know and see, that cannot be trusted.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
What do you think?

For what causes and conditions does the TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, in front of the people of JambudvÄ«pa, non-humans, and so forth, with various faculties and various beliefs, manifest mean and lowly conduct, and in front of the devas, nÄgas, yaká¹£as, gandharvas, and so forth, speak of praising and extolling the merits of dhÅ«ta?
The Bodhisattva Who Subdues All Obstacles said:
World-Honored One!

For the sake of those sentient beings who are to be transformed, he manifests these events, and for those immeasurable newly-enlightened ones who practice the bodhisattva path but have not yet severed afflictions, the TathÄgata demonstrates the Dharma gates of antidotes.
Good man!
In this way, the bodhisattva attains the power of vows and only wears discarded robes in order to teach and guide sentient beings, not out of a lowly mind.
Good man!
For this reason, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva wears discarded robes.
Good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, endowed with ten qualities, receives and keeps the three robes.
What are the ten?

Namely, the mind is content, always having few desires, far from greed and seeking, far from hoarding, having nothing to hoard, no worry of loss, having no worry of loss, free from the suffering of loss, free from the suffering of loss, an evil mind does not arise, an evil mind being absent, no sorrow and distress, no sorrow and distress, nothing to seek and take, nothing to seek and take, able to practice, exhausting all afflictions.
Good man!
Because of contentment, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are content with whatever Dharma robes they obtain;
Because of contentment, they immediately attain few desires;ğŸ”½Because of few desires, they are far from greed and seeking;
Because of being free from greed and seeking, they have nothing to hoard;
Because of having nothing to hoard, there is no worry of loss;
Because of having no worry of loss, they do not give rise to suffering;ğŸ”½Because of having no suffering, an evil mind does not arise;
Because of having no evil mind, there is no sorrow and distress;
Because of having no sorrow and distress, there is nothing to seek and take;
Because of not seeking or grasping, one is able to cultivate and exhaust all afflictions.
Good man!
Thus, bodhisattvas who possess these ten qualities uphold the three robes.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities do not dwell in a state of lowliness or arrogance.
What are the ten?
Namely, not following greed, not following anger, not following delusion, and dwelling in peace - this is called not dwelling in a state of lowliness or arrogance;

Dwelling without resentment, dwelling without jealousy, dwelling without stinginess, dwelling without arrogance, dwelling without displaying one's own virtues, dwelling without seeking fame, dwelling without greed for profit, dwelling without despising others, and dwelling without self-importance.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess these ten qualities do not dwell in a state of lowliness or arrogance.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities beg for alms.
What are the ten?

Namely, to benefit all sentient beings, to go begging in sequence, to be free from craving and seeking, to be content with one's own sufficiency, to naturally enjoy giving, to be free from greedy thoughts, to know one's own limits regarding the alms food one receives, to head towards the auxiliary path, to skillfully accumulate wholesome roots, and to be free from the thought of accumulation.
Good man!
How do bodhisattvas benefit sentient beings and be free from the thought of accumulation?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see that sentient beings are poor, suffering, with meager merit and virtue, and have not planted good roots. For their benefit, they go begging for alms.

When entering a city or village to beg for food, they should well collect their thoughts and contemplate inwardly. They should not let their minds wander among objects, but should be dignified in deportment, with their faculties unmoving. They must not be negligent, looking at the ground seven feet ahead while walking with lowered head. They should not let their minds be scattered in regard to wholesome dharmas.
In this way, go begging in order, do not extend your hand too far, and hold the alms bowl in your chest.
If you enter the home of a wealthy elder, do not seek too much, know the proper amount to receive, and be satisfied with just one meal for the day, do not interfere with Dharma activities.

If there are many vicious dogs, cows, horses, elephants, and various birds and beasts that come to disturb you, or men, women, young, and old who speak viciously and jestingly, or who argue, slander, and defame you, stay far away from such places.
When practicing the begging method, do not seek out of thirst or desire, do not seek by force, do not give rise to love and longing for the donors, and do not be angry or resentful.
Without thirst or longing, receive whatever is suitable, be self-sufficient, hold the alms bowl and return, go to your dwelling place, put away your robes and bowl, and wash your hands and feet.
If you see a Buddha image, you should respectfully make offerings and pay homage before entering the temple.
As for the food you eat, divide it into four parts:
one part for your fellow practitioners, one part to give to the poor, one part for animals, and one part for yourself.
Take the food in this way, without a greedy mind or a mind of expectation. Eat just enough to sustain yourself, neither too little nor too much, and take just the right amount of food.
Why is this?
If you eat too little, you will not be able to practice the Way;
if you eat too much, you will sleep and your body will be heavy, and you will not be able to study or sit in meditation.
Those who seek the Way should all be diligent and think like this:
'How can I fulfill the Dharma that assists the Way if I am lazy and indolent?'
If you are able to gather the Dharma that assists the Way, then you will not be attached to self;
If one is not attached to self, one can cut one's own flesh to feed sentient beings.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas, endowed with ten practices, beg for alms.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, endowed with ten practices, eat only one meal a day.
What are the ten?
Namely, sitting at the site of enlightenment, all the demon troops create terror but one sits unmoved;
sitting unmoved on the supramundane seat;ğŸ”½sitting unmoved in supramundane wisdom;
sitting unmoved in supramundane cognition;
sitting unmoved in the samÄdhi of emptiness;
sitting unmoved in the realization of all dharmas;
sitting unmoved in the eightfold noble path;
sitting unmoved in true reality;
sitting unmoved in suchness;
sitting unmoved in omniscience.
What is meant by sitting once is only sitting on the Dharma seat, and therefore it is called eating one meal a day.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas see these ten dharmas and eat only one meal a day while sitting.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten dharmas uphold not eating again.
What are the ten?
Namely, after one meal, they have no hopes, no attachments, and do not accept invitations to eat or not eat, whether it is the right time or not;

If they can cure the body with various medicinal foods, namely ghee, oil, sugar, honey, white sugar, roots, or fruits, even if they see others eating, they do not give rise to anger, greed, or stinginess;

If a bodhisattva does not eat after noon and becomes sick and suffers, if because of the illness they fear losing their life or fear neglecting practicing the Way, they should use it without doubt, knowing that this medicine can cure this illness.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas, endowed with these ten qualities, do not eat again.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, endowed with ten qualities, dwell in the wilderness.
What are the ten?

Namely, long practicing pure conduct, well understanding the Vinaya, unimpaired faculties, being very learned, upholding the virtuous practices of precepts, being free from attachment and fear of self, like a wild deer, subduing one's physical behavior, cultivating physical lightness and agility, heading towards tranquility, and being free from mental distress.
Good man!
What is meant by bodhisattvas long practicing pure conduct up to being free from mental distress?
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, since leaving the household life, have in the true Dharma and Vinaya fully perfected the precepts, the three wheels are pure, well understand the characteristics of dharmas, are fully endowed with deportment, come and go at the proper times, and have thoroughly penetrated the upper, middle, and lower grades of the path and Dharma taught by the TathÄgata. They no longer seek others, are unmoved, do not cling to heterodox theories or all external scriptures, and are clear about the meaning and words of the Buddha's true Dharma.
They fully know the methods of confessing transgressions and non-transgressions, and avoid all transgressions. They respectfully uphold the true Dharma and frequently repent.

They disclose all evil dharmas and reform past mistakes. They thoroughly understand the source of these offenses and avoid them. They also fully understand upper, middle, and lower karma and the upper, middle, and lower retributions.
Because they have already attained faith and understanding, they uphold the true Dharma. Their eyes, ears, and other faculties are complete, and their bodies are without defect.

Abiding in the araá¹‡ya - 'ara' means 'no' and 'á¹‡ya' means 'dispute' - dwelling in the mountains and forests, not disputing with the world. In this forest, there is no conflict or disturbance, not too close or far, and it is easy to beg for food.
In these mountains and forests, there is pure water, no difficult situations, and it is easy to obtain water for washing.
The trees provide shade, and there are plenty of flowers and fruits, with no vicious animals.
There are natural stone chambers that are not too steep, and it is not difficult to climb up.

In this quiet and secluded place, alone without companions, one should recall and recite the teachings one has heard, remembering them day and night, six times a day, without forgetting. Recite them with a voice that is neither too loud nor too soft, and do not neglect the recitation.

Subdue the senses and do not let them run wild. Focus the mind and contemplate without giving rise to distraction. Take joy in peacefully upholding the scriptures, grasping the three characteristics of stillness, arousal, and letting go, and do not be attached to sleep.
If there are kings, ministers, elders, or people who come to visit, you should say to them:
'Welcome, welcome.
' If they come to your dwelling, invite the great king to sit down, and sit in an appropriate place.
If the king can sit, both of you should sit;
if the king does not sit, do not sit alone.
If the king is restless and does not take your seat, you should speak affectionately:
'Great king!
This mountain forest land has great benefits. Åšramaá¹‡as who uphold precepts, have moral virtue, and are learned dwell here without fear, danger, or robbery.'
If that king is peaceful and tranquil, and is able to listen to the Dharma, then expound it for him;
if he does not enjoy extensive explanations, then give a brief explanation in accordance with disenchantment;
if he does not enjoy listening to the Dharma of disenchantment, then praise the Buddha's unsurpassed merits.

If the elders and people come, according to their abilities, I will expound the essential Dharma for them, causing them all to give rise to the mind of faith in the Dharma, and also causing them to uphold the three refuges and precepts, causing these people to give rise to a joyful mind, benefiting themselves and benefiting others.
In order to cause the arising of all evils and afflictions to be extinguished, one cultivates much learning and is not attached to self;
Because of not being attached to self, one abides in the mountains and forests, without worries, fears, or thoughts of weakness, and does not give rise to terror.
Approaching tranquility, far from clamor, dwelling alone like a deer, with few desires and contentment.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas dwelling in the mountains are not like deer, frightened and running away, not grasping their losses.
As for being like deer, they stay far from towns, villages, and homes, thinking:
'Because of being close to bad people, one may lose one's life.
In this way, the bodhisattva avoids the hustle and bustle of men, women, young and old, and thinks like this:
'Associating with these people will cause me to lose the wholesome roots I have cultivated in the past, and will give rise to distraction.

' In this way, always giving rise to a fearful mind, he abides in tranquility, gives rise to a mind of disgust towards the world, and abides in the mountains and forests, only seeing merits, only seeing tranquility, only seeing the ultimate, only seeing peace and joy, without a sorrowful mind, without a confused mind, not befriending evil companions, not obstructing the merits of tranquility in the mountains, and upholding and practicing all wholesome dharmas.
Good man!
In this way, the bodhisattva, endowed with these ten dharmas, abides in the araá¹‡ya.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, endowed with ten kinds of dharmas, rely on the foot of a tree.
What are the ten?

Namely, the place of dependence is under a tree, not too close or too far from the village, without thorns, poisonous plants, or filthy miscellaneous places, the tree leaves are not withered, it is not a place for monkeys, a place for birds' nests, a tree not inhabited by evil birds and beasts, a place without evil people or dangers, a place of dependence under a tree where the body is comfortable, the mind is not depressed, and the mind rests in peace.
Good man!
In this way, a bodhisattva possesses these ten dharmas and relies on being under a tree.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas possess ten dharmas and sit in the open air.
What are the ten?

Namely, in winter, summer, and spring, one should not stay too close to a threshing place, not too close to trees or dense places, not in dangerous mountains, not too close to rivers, not blocking cold, not blocking wind, not blocking rain, not blocking heat, not blocking frost and dew - only except when sick.
If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is sitting in the open air but has a physical illness and is unable to practice the Dharma, he should stay in a temple, thinking like this:
'The Buddhas, the TathÄgatas, have established the dhÅ«ta practices only to eliminate all afflictions.

I should follow the Buddha's teachings and practices. Although I stay in a temple, I should learn right effort, to eliminate afflictions, not to be lazy, distracted, or idle, and although I live in a temple, I should not give rise to attachment.'
He further thinks like this:
'Such temples are all built by donors for the benefit of all those who cultivate the Way.
Therefore, I should not give rise to the thought of ownership towards the temple. Although I stay in the temple, I should always be free from the thought of being in a temple.'
Good man!
In this way, a bodhisattva who possesses these ten dharmas sits in the open air.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten kinds of dharmas dwell in charnel grounds.
What are the ten?

Namely, if one abides in the middle, one often gives rise to disgust, always thinking of death, thinking of being devoured by the eighty thousand kinds of worms, thinking of red blood, thinking of blue and swollen flesh, thinking of foul odors, thinking of bloating, thinking of blood-smeared [corpse], thinking of pus and rot, thinking of dismemberment, thinking of skeletons.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who dwell in charnel grounds always give rise to compassion and pity for sentient beings, uphold pure precepts, are fully endowed with dignified conduct, always eat vegetarian food, and sustain their lives.
Why is it so?
Good man!

In this charnel ground, there are non-human beings who rely on it as their dwelling, and eat human blood and flesh. If they see bodhisattvas eating fish and meat, they will give rise to evil thoughts and come to disturb them.

Bodhisattvas who live in charnel grounds should enter monasteries, first worshiping the Buddha's stÅ«pas, then paying respects to the elders, and after respectfully completing these duties, stand to one side. They should not sit in the seats of the saá¹ƒgha.
Why is this?
The Dharma of bodhisattvas protects the minds of worldly laypeople. Bodhisattvas who live in charnel grounds turn away from worldly foolish beings, not contradicting the sages.

If invited to sit on a private seat, a bodhisattva may sit there only if the saá¹ƒgha's mind is unchanged, so as not to cause the person to regret it later. With a humble mind, they should think of themselves as a caá¹‡á¸Äla.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who possess these ten qualities live in charnel grounds.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities sit in meditation without lying down.
What are the ten?

Namely, not sitting or sleeping in order to torment the body, not sitting or sleeping in order to disturb the mind, not sitting with a withered body, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas generally sit but do not sleep, but in order to fulfill the practices for attaining enlightenment, in order to be single-minded, in order to head towards the right path, in order to sit at the site of enlightenment, in order to benefit sentient beings, in order to extinguish all afflictions, they sit but do not lie down.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who possess these ten dharmas always sit but do not lie down.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten dharmas spread their sitting mats as appropriate.
What are the ten?

Namely, in the place where one sits, one does not engage in excessive activity, nor does one seek to have others arrange the seat, nor does one make gestures to have others arrange the seat, one sits wherever one finds leaves or grass, if there is a place on the ground with many insectsâ€”ants, mosquitoes, gadflies, flies, and fleasâ€”one completely avoids it, as well as places where there are burrows and cremation grounds;
if one is resting, one lies on the right side, with the upper and lower legs stacked, the kÄá¹£Äya covering the body, with right mindfulness and a focused mind, visualizing light;
always maintaining the thought of awakening, one temporarily lies down to sleep, not taking pleasure in sleep, not taking pleasure in the side, but only adjusting the body;
maintaining the four elements, not allowing them to become excessively exhausted, using one's efforts day and night to cultivate the Dharma that assists the Way.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who possess these ten dharmas sit wherever a seat is offered.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten kinds of dharmas have minds that accord with principle.
What are the ten?

Namely, cultivating the contemplation of impurity a lot, cultivating the contemplation of compassion a lot, cultivating the contemplation of the twelve links of dependent origination a lot, well understanding the dharmas that defile the mind, cultivating the characteristics of emptiness a lot, cultivating signlessness a lot, cultivating the concentration of the mind a lot, having no wishes or aspirations, always cultivating without ceasing and not allowing regret, and being replete with the precepts.
Good man!
How do bodhisattvas cultivate the contemplation of impurity a lot?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwell alone in seclusion, do not go among people, hide in the mountains and forests, and single-mindedly silently contemplate, adjusting and straightening their minds.
They make their bodies straight, sit cross-legged, and see the bending and stretching, bowing and raising of their limbs and joints, giving rise to a mind of disgust and detachment.
They should contemplate the thirty-six substances within the body, one after another, and not contemplate anything outside the skin.
They should contemplate in this way:

Even the various kinds of food and drink, delicious flavors, and pure and clean [food] of sentient beings, whether coarse or fine, as soon as they enter the stomach become impure. When they touch the internal fire, they then become foul-smelling and rotten, and the foul air goes against the nose, which is disliked by all in the world.
Such a body is what all infants, ordinary beings, and sentient beings cling to. One should rely on the teachings of the sages and use good wisdom to contemplate it as it truly is.
Therefore, I should not love this body that is a stinking place. For this reason, I should become disgusted with it.
In this way, the bodhisattva cultivates the contemplation of impurity extensively.
How does the bodhisattva cultivate the contemplation of loving-kindness and compassion extensively?
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva dwells alone in a quiet place, as explained before, and thinks like this in the previous sequence:
'These sentient beings have much anger, resentment, and hatred, and create evil karma. They entangle their enemies and blame their masters without reason.
If I can completely eliminate all anger in the past, present, and future, only then will I sit on the bodhi seat.
' Thinking like this, contemplating with profound insight and true compassion, not just speaking with the mouth.
How do bodhisattvas cultivate the contemplation of the twelve links of dependent origination?
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to desire, anger, or ignorance, they think like this:
'Desire, anger, and ignorance arise due to conditions, and these conditions also arise due to conditions. In these dharmas that arise from conditions, there is no self-nature, they are all false.
What wise person would create wounds on their own body with false dharmas that arise from conditions?'
How do bodhisattvas skillfully understand defiled mental states?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe these defiled dharmas, whether in their own minds or in the minds of others, and cannot measure or assess them. In order to extinguish these causes and conditions, they should observe them.
What are they?

Namely, not respecting the Buddha, not respecting the Dharma, not respecting the Saá¹ƒgha, not respecting the precepts, not respecting fellow students, whether old or young, and not being respectful - this is called a defiled mental dharma.
Only valuing oneself and despising others, racing and scattering in various realms,
turning one's back on nirvÄá¹‡a, attached to the views of self, person, sentient being, and life-possessor,
clinging to the view of emptiness, clinging to the view of annihilation, clinging to permanence and impermanence, hating and resenting the virtuous,
associating with the foolish and ordinary, distancing oneself from those who uphold the precepts, befriending those who violate the precepts,
avoiding good and virtuous friends, slandering the profound scriptures of the buddhas, and in regard to the profound Dharma,
They give rise to fearful appearances, laziness and indolence, and give rise to thoughts of inferiority within themselves, lacking
authority, stammering in speech, giving rise to doubts in inappropriate places, doubting what should not be doubted,
and doubting what should not be doubted. They are bound by the various hindrances and bonds, deceiving worldly people, and
engaging in flattery. They are drowsy from sleep, only greedy for offerings, seeking fame, relying on
their clans, being attached to their relatives, tainted by wrong views, relying on their countries, and longing for
the masses. They study sorcery, logic, and worldly literature, and abandonğŸ”½the true Dharma, neglecting the practice of the Way. They are busy with unwholesome dharmas, and do not strive in
virtuous deeds. They hate and slander renunciant people, but only like to sing and praise
the colors of women, and praise young men and women. They do not enjoyğŸ”½silence
They are not at ease in the wilderness, are agitated and unhappy, and do not know the proper extent of good and evil
, do not go to ask about what should be respected, do not associate with, make offerings to, or recite the scriptures
, do not know the proper time, do not avoid criticism in their actions, and cannot uphold the precepts whether they are light
or heavy.

They have no fear of evil dharmas, their faculties are dull, their ignorance and hindrances are heavy, their minds are always agitated, their evil karma is quick, they have no scruples, walk alone at will, take the Dharma by improper means, and are worried and sorrowful.
They do not contemplate the past, present, or future, thinking, 'What did I do in the past? What am I doing now? What will I do in the future?'
They do not contemplate such things at all.

They think the inconceivable is conceivable, the immeasurable is measurable, the unobtainable is obtainable, the impure is pure, the non-liberating is liberating, the non-path is the path, and what has not been attained is attained.
'I am very busy and have not yet attained the practice of goodness.'
'I am an ordinary person, how can I practice the teachings of the noble path?'
They are attached to worldly affairs and push aside the days of liberation, avoiding the subtle merits and wholesome roots.

They cannot praise the Mahayana and Hinayana, and if they see those who have faith and joy in the Buddha's true Dharma, they slander them. They delight in disputes, like to argue right and wrong, are coarse and speak harshly, are arrogant and haughty, are evil and abusive, are abrupt and restless, look down on others, speak meaningless words, take pleasure in discussing others' faults, and like to speak what should not be spoken. They take pleasure in idle chatter and are addicted to games.
These kinds of things are called defiled dharmas, which can defile the mind but are well understood.
In order to extinguish all idle chatter, cultivate emptiness extensively and enter meditation to regulate the mind.
Cultivating emptiness like this, in this realm, follow the mind wherever it becomes attached.
Seek out the essence of this place, and in the end there will be nothing.
Because there is nothing, one penetrates emptiness.
The objects of perception and the perceiving mind should both be observed. Having made this observation, both the mind and objects are found to be non-existent, and one penetrates emptiness.

Because one penetrates emptiness, in order to cultivate the signless one focuses the mind and enters into meditative concentration. All appearances manifest as similar. Observing them well, one sees that they are not signs.
Having understood that they are not signs, one does not obtain one's own body and thus has no bodily signs;
Having attained the signless, one is not attached to one's own body;
Because one is not attached to the body, one does not obtain any external objects.

One does not discriminate external objects and does not shift the mind elsewhere. Since the mind does not move with regard to internal and external signs, in order to extinguish the sign of the signless, one does not give rise to sorrow or joy in cultivating the practice of meditation.
Although one attains this concentration, habitual tendencies are still numerous;
In order to extinguish habitual tendencies, one always cultivates this concentration, with the mind continuing in succession without interruption, just like a firebrand.
Abiding in Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ, vipaÅ›yanÄ is the contemplation of the truth of reality, and Å›amatha is the silent stillness of the one mind.
Because the mind attains concentration, later on one does not give rise to regret;
Because one does not give rise to regret, one gives rise to a joyful mind.
Why is there joy?
It is due to the purity of the precepts.
All bodhisattvas are replete with the precepts, and the pure mind is subsumed in accordance with principle.
Why is this so?
It is because the precepts are pure that the concentrated mind can be accomplished.
Therefore, it is called being in accordance with principle.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas are replete with ten dharmas, and the concentrated mind is in accordance with principle.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are replete with ten dharmas in upholding the sÅ«tras.ğŸ”½Namely, in order to protect the true Dharma, one goes to listen and does not do so for the sake of livelihood;
In order to protect the true teaching, one diligently listens to the true Dharma, not for the sake of gain;
In order to ensure the continuity of the Three Jewels, they diligently seek much learning, not for worldly gain;
In order to benefit those who study the Great Vehicle, they cultivate much learning, not for praise;
In order to benefit sentient beings who have no protector, they cultivate much learning;
In order to bring peace and happiness to sentient beings afflicted by the three kinds of suffering, they cultivate much learning;
In order to enable sentient beings who lack the eye of wisdom to obtain the eye of wisdom, they cultivate much learning;
In order to expound the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas for those of the Lesser Vehicle, they cultivate much learning;
In order to expound the bodhisattva path for those of the Great Vehicle, they cultivate much learning;
In order to personally realize the unsurpassed wisdom, they cultivate much learning, not seeking the Lesser Vehicle and cultivating much learning.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas who possess these ten qualities uphold the scriptures.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities uphold the Vinaya.
What are the ten?

Namely, thoroughly understanding the Vinaya and the essence of the Vinaya, the profundity of the Vinaya, the subtlety of the Vinaya, what is an offense and what is not an offense, natural offenses and offenses created by precepts, the basis of learning the PrÄtimoká¹£a, the Vinaya of Å›rÄvakas, and the Vinaya of bodhisattvas.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who possess ten qualities uphold the Vinaya.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess ten qualities are fully endowed with dignified deportment and conduct.
What are the ten?

Namely, having already studied the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas, having already studied the teachings of the pratyekabuddhas, and having already studied the teachings of the bodhisattvas, having studied in this way, they are fully endowed with dignified deportment;

They completely avoid all places of conduct that are unsuitable for Å›ramaá¹‡as. For these reasons, they do not go to unsuitable places, do not go at unsuitable times, and do not go to unsuitable countries;
The places where Å›ramaá¹‡as should practice are not lost, and do not allow Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as to criticize and ridicule.

As for deportment, it accords with principle, and further encourages others to abide in this Dharma, causing those who practice the Dharma to be endowed with all deportments, orderly and subtle, inwardly harmonious, without falsity.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who are endowed with these ten dharmas are complete in their deportment and practice.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who are endowed with ten dharmas have no stinginess or greed in their minds and are also free from jealousy.
What are the ten?

Namely, being able to give oneself, and also encouraging others to practice giving, praising giving, giving rise to a joyful mind upon seeing others giving, encouraging and praising them to make them rejoice.
One does not think like this:ğŸ”½Only give to me, do not give to others;
Only make me abundant, do not allow others to obtain.
should think like this:

'May all sentient beings obtain the requisites of happiness and various means of livelihood, whether in the mundane or supramundane realms, and may they be endowed with happiness. The ascetic practices I am now undertaking are for the benefit and happiness of these sentient beings.
Therefore, I should not give rise to stinginess, greed, or jealousy towards sentient beings.'
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who are endowed with ten qualities have no stingy, greedy, or jealous thoughts.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who are endowed with ten qualities have an attitude of equality towards all sentient beings.
What are the ten?

Namely, being impartial in one's actions towards all beings, having no angry or resentful thoughts towards any being, practicing giving, upholding precepts, cultivating patience, being diligent and vigorous, skillfully contemplating meditation, cultivating the wisdom of prajÃ±Ä, not relying on the two extremes in cultivating the mind, giving rise to an impartial mind towards all beings, and practicing the six pÄramitÄs in order to attain this Dharma.
The burning house of birth and death is ablaze with suffering. Having escaped oneself, one further saves other people and causes them to escape.
With an impartial mind, one does not give rise to thoughts of separation and obstruction, and has no aversion or attachment.
Good man!
It is like a wealthy elder who has only six children. He loves and pities them all equally.
These children are still young and foolish, not understanding matters, crawling around and playing.
The long-lived one's house was burned by fire, with raging flames and blazing fires everywhere. These children each went east and west.
Good man!
What do you think?
At that time, did the long-lived one ever have this thought:
'I should first save one child, and then use skillful means to save the other children?'
The Bodhisattva Who Subdues All Obstacles replied:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
World-Honored One!
Why is it so?
Because the long-lived one equally saves and delivers all his children, without any biased mind, and pulls out those who are closest first.
Good man!

In this way, all kinds of sentient beings are all the infants of the Bodhisattva. They do not understand suffering and happiness, have no knowledge or understanding, and are in the burning house of birth and death, each dwelling in the six realms.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, according to the maturity of their wholesome roots, first rescue and liberate those who are mature and establish them in abiding in the pure dharma realm, outside of birth and death.
Good sons!
In this way, bodhisattvas, endowed with these ten dharmas, practice an impartial mind towards all sentient beings.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, endowed with ten dharmas, sincerely respect and make offerings to the buddhas.
What are the ten?

Namely, making offerings to the Dharma is making offerings to the Buddha, not using wealth and goods is making offerings to the TathÄgata, for the sake of bringing peace and benefit to sentient beings, for the sake of embracing all sentient beings, for the sake of accomplishing the wholesome roots of sentient beings, not abandoning the pure precepts that are received, not neglecting the practices and deeds of all bodhisattvas, as the Dharma is taught, the body is able to practice, practicing in this way, the mind is without fatigue, not abandoning the mind of unsurpassed enlightenment.
Thus, respectfully making offerings to the buddhas does not require material wealth, but if one is able to practice the true Dharma of the buddhas, that is making offerings to the buddhas.
Why is this?
Making offerings to the Dharma is making offerings to all tathÄgatas.

This Dharma benefits all beings and causes them to leave the world. If one turns away from the practices of the bodhisattvas, then one's body and speech will be at odds, and one will not be able to fulfill one's vows, will become weary in mind, and will abandon bodhi, and will not be able to benefit sentient beings.
Why is this?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas seek anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi only for the sake of benefiting all sentient beings. If there were no sentient beings, there would also be no bodhisattvas attaining perfect enlightenment.
Good man!
You should contemplate in this way:
The Dharma is precisely the Buddha, because all buddhas have the Dharma as their body.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas, endowed with ten qualities, sincerely respect and make offerings to the buddhas.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, endowed with ten qualities, eliminate pride.
What are the ten?
Namely, leaving home life behind, diligently seeking the path, relatives, friends, and all family members no longer have any connection, as if one were a dead person.
Therefore, there is no pride;
Changing one's appearance, wearing dyed robes, now seeking something different, therefore there is no pride;
Shaving the head, carrying a bowl, begging for food from house to house to sustain this body, therefore not giving rise to pride;
Because of begging for food, giving rise to a humble mind, like a caá¹‡á¸Äla, one should not be proud;
Now my life depends on others for sustenance, receiving others' alms, like a starving dog despised by people, one should not be proud;
I should continue the venerable field of merit, I should not be proud;
One should not be arrogant when one's fellow students see and rejoice.
One should not be arrogant when upholding various dignified deportments, orderly and proper.
One should not give rise to arrogance when thinking, I shall attain the Dharma that I have not yet attained.
One should not give rise to arrogance when abiding in cultivating much patience among various sentient beings with bad natures.
Good man!
Thus, bodhisattvas, endowed with these ten dharmas, eliminate arrogance.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, endowed with ten dharmas, have minds that are mostly pure.
What are the ten?

Namely, being upheld by meritorious karma, possessing past wholesome roots and past causes, being endowed with right views, not attached to wrong doctrines, being unmovable, not serving other teachers, harboring purity within, being without flattery, having a mind without arrogance, and also not being deceptive.

Their minds are straightforward, endowed with wisdom, their faculties are clear and sharp, they are free from all obstructions, their mental activities are pure, they are close to good friends, they stay away from bad friends, they subdue arrogance, they diligently seek the subtle truth, when listening to the Dharma they do not look for faults, and they fully understand the merits of the Buddhas.
Good man!
In this way, bodhisattvas who possess these ten qualities have minds that are mostly pure.
Subduer of All Obstacles Bodhisattva said:
World-Honored One!
The merits of the Buddhas are inconceivable. How can I hear and understand this Dharma?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Listen attentively, I will now tell you a small part of the TathÄgata's merits for you.
Yes, World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to hear it.
The Buddha said:
Good man!

The TathÄgata's great compassion is perfect and complete, and he is completely impartial towards all sentient beingsâ€”just as he is impartial and compassionate towards one person, so it is also for all sentient beings throughout the Dharma realm.
Just as the realm of space pervades the realms of all sentient beings,
the TathÄgata's compassion pervades everywhere, being immeasurable and boundless, also like this, different from the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas.
Good sons!

The buddhas and tathÄgatas' teaching is inexhaustible, and for immeasurable eons it cannot be exhausted. With various names and various meanings, in an instant they speak the Dharma with a single voice for immeasurable assemblies, and according to their various kinds of sounds each gains understanding, being limitless and inexhaustible.
Good sons!
The buddhas and tathÄgatas' questions and answers are complete.

Suppose there were all the sentient beings in the ten directions, each asking the TathÄgata various questions simultaneously, the TathÄgata would be able to answer each and every one of them in a single instant, without obstruction or impediment, using the various languages and names of those sentient beings.
Good man!
The realm of the buddhas' meditative concentration is unobstructed.
Good man!

Suppose all sentient beings were at the stage of the ten grounds, and they simultaneously entered into hundreds of thousands of myriads of millions of meditative concentrations in a single instant, they would still not be able to reach the boundless realm of the TathÄgata's meditative concentration.
Good man!
The TathÄgata is fully endowed with an immeasurable form body.
Good man!

Suppose there were sentient beings who should be guided by the TathÄgata's body, in a single instant he would appear before all those sentient beings, manifesting the Buddha's body according to their wishes, and in a single instant manifesting various bodies.
Good man!
The TathÄgata is fully endowed with the divine eye with immeasurable realms.
Good man!

There are sentient beings who attain the divine eye, and they see the immeasurable and boundless forms in the various worlds, but the TathÄgata sees them all as clearly as an Ämalaka fruit in the palm of the hand.
Good man!
The TathÄgata's immeasurable divine ear realm.
Good man!

If there are sentient beings who attain the divine ear and fill the immeasurable and boundless worlds, according to the various sounds they hear, the TathÄgata can in a single instant hear all these sounds.
Good man!
The TathÄgata is fully endowed with the knowledge of others' minds, which is boundless, inexhaustible, and equal to space.
Good man!

Suppose there is a realm of all sentient beings with various thoughts, various contemplations, and various karmic activities. The TathÄgata is able to understand in a single thought all the immeasurable and boundless minds of all, as well as the karma they create and the retribution for that karma, and with unobstructed wisdom he fully understands them in the three times.
Good man!
The TathÄgata is always in meditation and has never forgotten it.
Why is it so?
The Buddha has no loss of mindfulness, his faculties are unmoving, and his inner mind is undisturbed.
Why is it so?
Because all afflictions and the habitual tendencies of afflictions are ultimately exhausted, he is always in tranquility.
Good man!
People with afflictions are confused in their inner minds and cannot attain meditation;
the TathÄgata is not like this.
The TathÄgata is no longer subject to afflictions or entanglements, is free from outflows, and is unconditioned. He has attained all dharmas and freely roams in the realm of all profound samÄdhis.
Good man!
The TathÄgata, abiding in a single deportment or a single samÄdhi, even up to nirvÄá¹‡a, always abides therein without moving, and therefore is always in samÄdhi.
Good man!
The buddhas, the tathÄgatas, having cultivated various practices for immeasurable eons, attained perfect enlightenment, which is inconceivable, indescribable, and boundless.
The Bodhisattva Who Subdues All Obstacles said:
World-Honored One!
Did the TathÄgata not cultivate merit for immeasurable eons?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Do not speak thus.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should not contemplate the realm of the TathÄgata.

The realm of the TathÄgata is inconceivable and indescribable. It is only for the sake of shallow and ordinary beings that it is said to be attained through cultivation over three incalculable eons, but in reality the bodhisattva's initial arousal of the mind is beyond measure.
The Bodhisattva Who Subdues All Obstacles said:
World-Honored One!
How fortunate!

These sentient beings who cultivate various wholesome roots, have already eliminated karmic hindrances, have given rise to much faith and understanding, and are close to enlightenment. Hearing the Buddha's merits, their minds give rise to joy. How much more so for those who, having heard, are able to fully accept, uphold, recite, explain, copy, and make offerings?
World-Honored One!
These sentient beings will soon attain the TathÄgata's merits, no different from today.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
It is so, it is so.

The TathÄgata accepts these sentient beings who have already planted wholesome roots in the presence of the Buddhas and respectfully served immeasurable Buddhas. These sentient beings, hearing the Buddha's merits, do not give rise to doubt.
Good man!

If good men or good women, for seven days and seven nights without any other thoughts, with their inner minds undisturbed, continuously recollecting moment by moment, recollecting the TathÄgata's such profound and subtle merits, wearing clean clothes, making various offerings, with mind after mind accomplishing [this], within those seven days they will see the TathÄgata's body complete with the thirty-two marks.
If there are those who are distracted, not level in their affairs, but always single-minded, at the time of death the TathÄgata will appear before them.
Bodhisattva Subduer of All Obstacles said:
World-Honored One!
Are there sentient beings who, upon hearing the TathÄgata's explanation of the TathÄgata's merits, give rise to disbelief?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

There are sentient beings who hear the Buddha speaking of the TathÄgata's merits, but with their evil speech and coarse words they scold and give rise to an angry mind, regarding the Dharma speaker as an enemy. Due to this cause and condition, after they leave this body they are born in the hells, where they experience immeasurable suffering.
Good man!
There are sentient beings who hear the Buddha's merits and give rise to joy. They regard the Dharma speaker as a good friend and give rise to the thought of the TathÄgata.
Good man!
These sentient beings have the utmost faith in the ultimate principle, and in the past they have already heard the TathÄgata's such merits.
These sentient beings say in the great assembly:
'I have heard the TathÄgata speak of the Buddha's merits in the past, no different from what is being spoken in the sÅ«tras today.'

At that time, the World-Honored One extended his tongue to cover his face. After covering his face, he covered his head. After covering his head, he covered his body. After covering his body, he covered the lion seat. After covering the lion seat, he covered the bodhisattvas and Å›rÄvaka assembly. After covering the Å›rÄvaka assembly, he covered the assembly of Åšakra, BrahmÄ, and the Four Heavenly Kings. In this way, he completely covered the great assembly and then retracted his tongue. He asked the great assembly:
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, has this tongue. Could he possibly tell a lie?
Good men!
You should have faith in the TathÄgata's words, which are certainly not false.
If you have faith in this sÅ«tra, for your sake in the future, it will bring long-lasting benefits and endless peace and happiness.
When these words were spoken, 84,000 bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas;
immeasurable and boundless sentient beings removed defilements and obscurations and attained the purity of the dharma eye within the Buddha's teachings;
Immeasurable sentient beings who had not yet given rise to the mind of enlightenment all at that time gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Immeasurable sentient beings who had not yet given rise to the bodhi mind all at that time gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
